name: Breath of Fire
summary: A rapid, rhythmic yogic breathing technique characterized by forceful exhalations and passive inhalations, often practiced in Kundalini yoga for energy, focus, and detoxification.
description: Breath of Fire (Kapalabhati in Sanskrit) is a dynamic pranayama technique involving quick, forceful exhalations through the nose powered by abdominal contractions, with passive inhalations in between. It is a core practice in Kundalini yoga and other pranayama traditions, said to cleanse the respiratory system, increase energy, sharpen mental focus, and stimulate digestion. The practice is considered both invigorating and cleansing, often used at the start of yoga sessions or meditation to awaken vitality.

metadata.session_duration: 1–5 minutes for beginners; up to 15 minutes for advanced practitioners
treatment_duration: Ongoing as part of yoga routine
metadata.training_required: Instruction recommended for safe technique, especially for beginners.
metadata.regulatory_status: Not regulated; part of traditional yoga teachings.

contraindications: Absolute: Pregnancy, uncontrolled hypertension, recent abdominal surgery
Relative: Cardiovascular disease, glaucoma, seizure disorders, respiratory illness (asthma, COPD)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe when taught and practiced correctly. Improper or overly forceful practice may cause dizziness, hyperventilation, or discomfort.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Low to moderate. Some small studies show benefits in stress reduction, cardiorespiratory health, and mood, but rigorous clinical data are limited.

sections.text: Breath of Fire stimulates the sympathetic nervous system through rapid diaphragmatic contractions, increasing oxygen uptake and circulation. It balances carbon dioxide levels, enhances alertness, and generates internal heat, which may support metabolic activity and detoxification.

sections.preparation: Sit upright in a cross-legged position with a straight spine. Place hands on knees or in a mudra. Close eyes and relax shoulders.
procedure: Begin with a deep inhalation through the nose.
Exhale forcefully through the nose by contracting the abdominal muscles.
Allow inhalation to occur passively between exhalations.
Maintain a rhythmic pace (e.g., 1–2 exhalations per second).
Continue for 1–5 minutes, rest, and repeat if desired.
sections.frequency: 1–2 times daily or integrated into yoga practice.
sections.duration: 1–15 minutes depending on level and tolerance.

special_considerations: Beginners should start slowly with guidance.
Practice on an empty stomach to avoid discomfort.

screening_required: Medical clearance for those with cardiovascular or respiratory conditions

lifestyle_recommendations: Practice in the morning for energy
Use before meditation or concentration tasks

sections.typical_session_cost: Free (self-practice); included in yoga classes or apps ($10–$30/session)
sections.total_treatment_cost: Minimal to moderate depending on class participation

items: Considered energizing rather than calming—contraindicated in cases of acute anxiety.
Should be taught with emphasis on safe technique to avoid strain.
Part of traditional yogic cleansing practices (Shatkarma).
